me.wobblyyyy.pathfinder2.robot.components

Class AbstractMotor

  • java.lang.Object
    • me.wobblyyyy.pathfinder2.robot.components.AbstractMotor
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Motor
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    EmptyMotor

    public class AbstractMotor
extends java.lang.Object
implements Motor
    An abstract implementation of the Motor interface. This implementation does a few things - namely, it adds minimum and maximum power values, as well as a feature called "lazy mode."

    Lazy Mode

    Lazy mode is a feature I saw in another robotics library. Unfortunately, I can't, for the life of me, remember the name of the team that wrote the library or the name of the library - if you happen to know what I'm talking about, do me a favor and insert that name right here. Anyways. Lazy mode conditionally calls the motor's actual set power method only if one of two conditions are met.
    • The amount of time that's elapsed since power was last actually set to the motor and the current time is greater than a minimum elapsed milliseconds value.
    • The difference between the current power value and the target power value exceeds the maximum power value delta.
    Lazy mode is designed to decrease CPU load and free up some busses by not requiring the device running the robot code to set power to the motor every single time the set power method is called. If there's such little difference between the power values that would be set to the motor, there's no point in wasting resources trying to do so.

    Since:
    0.0.0
    Author:
    Colin Robertson

        public AbstractMotor(java.util.function.Consumer<java.lang.Double> setPower,
                     java.util.function.Supplier<java.lang.Double> getPower)
        Create a new AbstractMotor using a Supplier and a Consumer.
        Parameters:
        setPower - a Consumer that accepts a double value. This consumer should perform some set of actions that actually sets power to the motor and makes it spin.
        getPower - a Supplier that returns the motor's current power. This method typically calls a provided method that queries the power from the physical motor. If such a method is not provided, you should go about making it function in some other way. Sorry!

      • AbstractMotor

        public AbstractMotor(java.util.function.Consumer<java.lang.Double> setPower,
                     java.util.function.Supplier<java.lang.Double> getPower,
                     boolean isInverted)
        Create a new AbstractMotor using a Supplier and a Consumer.
        Parameters:
        setPower - a Consumer that accepts a double value. This consumer should perform some set of actions that actually sets power to the motor and makes it spin.
        getPower - a Supplier that returns the motor's current power. This method typically calls a provided method that queries the power from the physical motor. If such a method is not provided, you should go about making it function in some other way. Sorry!
        isInverted - if this is true, all setPower and getPower operations will multiply any inputted/outputted power values by -1.

        isSetInverted - if this is true, all setPower operations will multiply the inputted power by -1.
        isGetInverted - if this is true, all getPower operations will multiply the outputted power by -1.

      • setMaxPowerGap

        public AbstractMotor setMaxPowerGap(double maxPowerGap)
        Set the maximum power gap. If the motor is operating in lazy mode, power will only physically be set to the motor if the difference between the motor's current power value and the new power value is greater than this value.
        Parameters:
        maxPowerGap - the maximum power gap.
        Returns:
        this, used for method chaining.

      • setPower

        public void setPower(double power)
        Set power to the motor.

        This method doesn't just set power to the motor. It also does a couple of other pretty cool things.

        • Ensure the motor's power value fits between the minimum and maximum power values. If the motor's power value is less than the minimum power value, the power will be set to the minimum power value. If the motor's power is greater than the maximum power value, the power will be set to the maximum power value.
        • Do some cool stuff related to "lazy mode." Go read the AbstractMotor class JavaDoc if you're confused about what this is.

        Specified by:
        setPower in interface Motor
        Parameters:
        power - the power value to set to the motor.
